channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: 25 Looted Artifacts Return to Italy
item.description: Italy’s art theft squad worked with American investigators to return items recovered from museuems, auction houses and private collections.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: A paramilitary officer near recovered Etruscan vases displayed on Tuesday in Rome.

item.title: Memo From Abuja: Former Strongman, Taking Over Presidency, Raises Hope in Nigeria
item.description: There is a palpable feeling of hope as Muhammadu Buhari gets set to take the oath of office Friday. Mostly, it stems from relief that his hapless predecessor is finally exiting.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Election posters supporting Muhammadu Buhari in March in Kaduna. Mr. Buhari, a former military dictator, is set to be sworn in as Nigeria’s president on Friday.

item.title: Netanyahu Wants Talks With Palestinians on Settlements, Officials Say
item.description: Prime Minister Netanyahu reportedly said he wants to negotiate over settlements in the occupied West Bank. Palestinian leaders rejected the idea as a ploy.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: China, Updating Military Strategy, Puts Focus on Projecting Naval Power
item.description: A new policy paper says Beijing plans to extend its naval power on the open seas in coming years, and not just patrol coastal waters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Chinese dredging vessels last week in the waters around Mischief Reef in the disputed Spratly Islands.

item.title: Jungle Camp in Malaysia Yields Graves and Signs of Migrant Abuse
item.description: Investigators on Tuesday revealed some of their grim discoveries at an encampment in the north, which they suspect was used by human traffickers.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: A Malaysian police officer stood guard on Tuesday at an abandoned camp believed to have been used by human traffickers to hold migrants in Bukit Wang Burma in the state of Perlis, which borders Thailand.

item.title: Iraqi Army and Shiite Militias Begin Push to Take Ramadi From ISIS
item.description: The offensive began Tuesday in the desert areas north and east of Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Jason Rezaian of Washington Post Goes on Trial in Iran
item.description: The trial, which is not open to the public, began in a Tehran courtroom, the semiofficial Tasnim news agency reported. The charges include espionage.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian, a correspondent for the Washington Post, in Tehran in 2013.

item.title: Muslim Frenchwomen Struggle With Discrimination as Bans on Veils Expand
item.description: The head coverings of observant Muslim women have become one of the most potent flash points in the nation’s tense relations with its Muslim population.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Observant Muslim women in France, whose head coverings can vary from head scarves tied loosely under the chin to tightly fitted caps and wimple-like scarves that hide every strand of hair, say the constant talk of new laws has made them targets of abuse.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Distiller Sued in Test of State v. Private Ownership
item.description: A family has sued the liquor maker Wuliangye over ownership of pits used to make baijiu, a powerful, clear liquor.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Inside the Wuliangye workshop where the 16 Ming dynasty fermentation pits are located.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Morality of Robotic War
item.description: Autonomous weapons shouldn't be banned, but governments must ensure that they are used in a way that retains accountability.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL C. HOROWITZ and PAUL SCHARRE

item.title: Migrant Crisis in Southeast Asia Shows Signs of Ebbing
item.description: While no one is willing to say there are no more migrant boats at sea, an absence of landings and a paucity of sightings suggest that the worst may be over.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Hopes ‘Blacklist’ Will Curb Its Travelers’ Misbehavior Abroad
item.description: With the number of overseas tourists from China surpassing 100 million, and many of those descending en masse in large tour groups, China is trying to ensure that they don’t abuse their welcome.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Malaysia Denies Entry to Joshua Wong, Hong Kong Democracy Activist
item.description: Mr. Wong, who was set to talk to youth groups about his experience leading pro-democracy demonstrations, said he was told that a “government order” barred his admission.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Joshua Wong, 18, was a prominent leader of the pro-democracy demonstrations that shut down major thoroughfares in Hong Kong for months.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: On Being African in Europe
item.description: We lack inspiring symbols and leaders: our Martin Luther Kings, our Rosa Parkses, our Obamas.
item.dc:creator: VITTORIO LONGHI

item.title: With ISIS in Cross Hairs, U.S. Holds Back to Protect Civilians
item.description: Many Iraqi commanders and some American officers say that exercising caution with airstrikes has harmed the coalition’s larger effort to destroy the Islamic State.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Islamic State fighters paraded along the streets of Raqqa, Syria, in 2014.

item.title: Fire Kills 38 at Seniors Home in China
item.description: With a rapidly aging population and an underfunded social security system, China faces increasing pressure to provide safe, affordable care for retirees.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Government Protests as Russia Bars Critic of Ukraine Policy
item.description: Germany protested Monday after Russia denied entry to a political ally of Chancellor Angela Merkel the day before.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Finland: Fighter Jet Exercises Begin
item.description: One of Europe’s largest fighter jet exercises began Monday amid increasing military tensions in the Nordic and Baltic region.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: Islamist Group Is Banned
item.description: The Ministry of Home Affairs said Monday that the Ansarullah Bangla Team had been banned in response to a request by the police because it has threatened and killed bloggers, writers and activists.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Business Briefing: China to Reduce Import Taxes to Spur Spending and Growth
item.description: China announced Monday that it would cut import taxes on clothing, cosmetics and some other goods by half as a new tactic to generate more consumer spending and economic growth.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
